basics.name: Daniel William Clarke
basics.label: Software Engineer
basics.summary:
*I enjoy building software as I see both the art and science that it requires. I find it very enjoyable to see how a particular project or problem captivates me.*

I am an engaged and quality focused full stack software engineer.

I am always seeking to grasp bleeding edge technologies and practices in cloud, micro service architecture. software development, cyber security, CI/CD, SOLID and TDD.

I am currently leading a team of 4 software engineers, though I never thought that management would be something I would venture into, I am enjoying the challenge, and looking forward to the opportunities this role may yield!

work.summary: 14 month internship with Schlumberger. Where my main role was to continue the ongoing development of a simulation and software integration test platform for both prototype research algorithms and models and commercial Schlumberger products.

As part of an international team, spread between Gatwick UK, Faroe Islands, Pune, and Houston. I was a software engineer / architect developing the latest iteration of an Oil and Gas industry cloud based upstream learning simulator, OilSim.

Working within a Cloud Infrastructure Team for Seismic / Subsurface Exploration Oil and Gas projects. Using a polyglot technology stack to build solutions for critical work streams that included; building and maintaining micro services to bridge the gap between next gen and legacy platforms, as well as building infrastructure providing our clients access to powerful seismic interpretation machine learning.

projects.name: Semi Autonomous Finite State Machines
projects.summary: To complete my final year at Nottingham Trent University, I researched and developed an application capable of the generation and deployment of semi-autonomous supervisory controllers for process automation. Upon completion I was then able return to Schlumberger Gould Research to demonstrate and integrate my solution with their drilling simulation test platform and autonomously drove a physical miniature drilling rig live.
